thread.title: 27 farmers markets to pick up fresh, local ingredients in metro Phoenix
thread.title_full: 27 farmers markets to pick up fresh, local ingredients in metro Phoenix

author: Suzanne Condie Lambert , The Republic | azcentral.com
title: 27 farmers markets to pick up fresh, local ingredients in metro Phoenix
text:
Roadrunner Park Market | This market, named one of the country's best farmers markets by Cooking Light, hosts nearly 60 local farmers and food makers. Expect locally harvested flour, fresh picked kale, baked goods, goat cheese, salsas and more. The Saturday and Wednesday market includes produce grown by prolific organic farmer Bob McClendon of McClendon's Select. Other vendors include Noble Bread, Arizona Microgreens, Horny Toad Farm and John's Amish Country. The market also includes cooking demonstrations, food trucks and live music. | Details: 9 a.m.-1 p.m. through April and 8 a.m.-1 p.m. Wednesdays. 5757 N. Central Ave., Phoenix. uptownmarketaz.com. (Photo: Ben Moffat/The Republic) 
565 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Sure there are a few farmers markets that brave Arizona summers, but now is when most are gearing up for another season of wholesome outdoor shopping. Check with your favorite market to learn when it closes for the year, or for changes in hours for those that remain year-round, and remember: Offerings are subject to change. Here's this season's list of Valley markets.
RELATED: Primer on Uptown Farmers Market in Phoenix | 3 healthful recipes from Joy Bus Diner in Phoenix | Eat well, live well with these 4 healthy recipes | Shop smarter: Arizona spring/summer produce guide 
PHOENIX Vincent's Saturday Market James Beard Award-winning chef Vincent Guerithault's influence touches every corner of this European-style market. Shop for buttery croissants, imported olive oil, local honey, mustard, artisan breads and local produce. After browsing, dine on made-to-order omelets and crepes, tacos, paella, pizzas, pastas, panini and chocolate desserts. Wine and champagne are sold by the glass, bottle and case. Items imported from France include lavender soaps and tablecloths.
Details: 9 a.m.-1 p.m. Saturdays starting Oct. 22 to early May. 3930 E. Camelback Road, Phoenix. vincentsoncamelback.com .
Phoenix Public Market | This urban market offers downtown Phoenix residents and workers a place to grocery shop. The market showcases seasonal produce from top local growers and artisan foods including grass-fed beef, quail eggs, cheese curds, all-natural horseradish, homemade caramels, shrimp ceviche, vegan and gluten-free foods, cheeses, French breads, pastries, pasta, garlic pickles, local pork, salsas and relishes. Artisans also sell wares as diverse as goat-milk soap and watercolors. | Details: 8 a.m.-noon Saturdays year-round. 721 N. Central Ave., Phoenix. phoenixpublicmarket.com.   (Photo: David Kadlubowski/The Republic) 
Phoenix Public Market This urban market offers downtown Phoenix residents and workers a place to grocery shop. The market showcases seasonal produce from top local growers and artisan foods including grass-fed beef, quail eggs, cheese curds, all-natural horseradish, homemade caramels, shrimp ceviche, vegan and gluten-free foods, cheeses, French breads, pastries, pasta, garlic pickles, local pork, salsas and relishes. Artisans also sell wares as diverse as goat-milk soap and watercolors.
Details: 8 a.m.-noon Saturdays May-Sep, 8 a.m.-1 p.m. Saturdays Oct.-Apr. 721 N. Central Ave., Phoenix. phoenixpublicmarket.com .
Roadrunner Park Market The state’s oldest farmers market offers one of the largest selections of produce, including locally grown Asian produce, heirloom tomatoes and organic basil, as well as fresh chickens and grass-fed lamb. About 55 vendors sell specialty foods, including cupcakes, jam, jerky, chili pies, wild salmon, tamales, green-chile stew and tortilla soup. The market, which accepts credit cards and EBT cards, also has nursery stock and worms for gardeners.
Details: Open Saturdays 8 a.m.-1 p.m. Oct.-May, 7-11a.m. June-Sep. 3501 E. Cactus Road, Phoenix. arizonacommunityfarmersmarkets.com .
Anthem Farmers Market This market hosts a handful of farmers and local food makers selling salsas, breads, desserts and tamales. You'll also find vendors selling plants and seeds. Arizona ranchers peddle their grass-fed beef.
Details: 9 a.m.-1 p.m. Sundays, reopening Oct. 30. Anthem Community (upper) Park, 41703 N. Gavilan Peak Parkway. arizonacommunityfarmersmarkets.com .
Uptown Farmers Market This market, named one of the country's best farmers markets by Cooking Light , hosts nearly 60 local farmers and food makers. Expect locally harvested flour, fresh picked kale, baked goods, goat cheese, salsas and more. The Saturday and Wednesday market includes produce grown by prolific organic farmer Bob McClendon of McClendon's Select. Other vendors include Noble Bread, Arizona Microgreens, Horny Toad Farm and John's Amish Country. The market also includes cooking demonstrations, food trucks and live music.
Details: 9 a.m.-1 p.m. Wednesdays Oct.-June, 8 a.m.-noon Saturdays May-Sept. and 9 a.m.-1p.m. Saturdays Oct.-April. Wednesdays. 5757 N. Central Ave., Phoenix. uptownmarketaz.com .

You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 1 of 20 2 of 20 3 of 20 4 of 20 5 of 20 6 of 20 7 of 20 8 of 20 9 of 20 10 of 20 11 of 20 12 of 20 13 of 20 14 of 20 15 of 20 16 of 20 17 of 20 18 of 20 19 of 20 20 of 20 Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide Desert Ridge Farmers Market at Cashman Park Shop for Polish goodies, ceviche, avocado and olive oils, barbecue sauces, local honey, fresh produce, cupcakes, dried fruits, pasta sauces, nuts, coffee, mustard, homemade horseradish and vegan drinks. Bring your dull chef knife to the market’s knife sharpener.
Details: 10 a.m.-1 p.m. third Sunday of the month. N. 44th Place, Phoenix. azfarmersmarkets.us .
WEST VALLEY Glendale Farmers Market The downtown market, which had its first season last spring, features brush-fed beef, crafts, food vendors and restaurateurs. The Saturday-morning markets are in the parking lot of the First United Methodist Churchvin the tree-lined Catlin Court Historic District.
Details: 9 a.m.-1 p.m. Jan. 14 and 28, Feb. 11 and 25, March 11 and 25, April 8 and 22, and May 6 and 20. 7102 N. 58th Drive. http://www.glendalefarmersmarket.org/home.html 
Peoria Farmer's Market at Park West | This market draws 60 to 100 vendors every Saturday, selling fresh produce, natural meats, wild fish, fresh-baked goods, fresh eggs, raw honey, local dairy and handmade goods and gifts. Food trucks and kids activities also featured. | Details: 9 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturdays through April. Park West, 9744 W. Northern Ave., Peoria. mommasorganicmarket.com.   (Photo: Cheryl Evans/The Republic) 
Peoria Farmer's Market at Park West (Momma's Organic Market) This market draws 60 to 100 vendors every Saturday, selling fresh produce, natural meats, wild fish, fresh-baked goods, fresh eggs, raw honey, local dairy and handmade goods and gifts. Food trucks and kids activities also featured.
Details: 9 a.m.-2 p.m. Saturdays through April. Park West, 9744 W. Northern Ave., Peoria. mommasorganicmarket.com .
Corte Bella Market Moreno Farms sells in-season produce while local food makers peddle homemade, all-natural jerky, pickles, olives, biscotti, hemp and chia seeds, herbs, frozen fish, grass-fed beef, pasta sauces and packaged soup mixes.
Details: 10 a.m.-1 p.m. second Wednesday of the month. 22135 N. Mission Drive, Sun City West. azfarmersmarkets.us .
Facebook Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Photos: Foods that matter for a healthy diet   Fullscreen Post to Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 
Beans and legumes | One study found that for every 20g intake of legumes (beans, lentils), the risk of death fell by 6 percent. Beans are the only food that can fit into both a vegetable and a protein category. And the color of the bean matters, too. Just like vegetables, more color equals higher antioxidant levels. Take note: Black beans contain 40 times the amount of antioxidants found in white beans.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Blueberries | They’re crammed with vitamins, minerals and antioxidants, natural compounds that decrease inflammation, guard cells against damage from free radicals and reduce the risk of certain cancers, heart disease, stroke and age-related brain diseases, such as Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Coffee | Coffee reduces the risk of age-related mental decline and may lower the risk of type 2 diabetes. A Finnish study found that people who regularly drank coffee during their middle-age years were significantly less likely to suffer dementia and Alzheimer’s later in life. Those who drank three to five cups daily had a 65 percent reduction in risk.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Dark chocolate | Residents of the San Blas Islands of Panama have virtually zero high blood pressure or heart disease. Researchers think it’s because they eat a lot of chocolate. Dark chocolate contains polyphenols, which are believed to lower blood pressure and improve the flexibility of blood vessels.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Green tea | It’s a rich source of antioxidants and has been shown to keep you mentally alert, help with weight loss, regulate cholesterol levels and prevent sun damage. There is preliminary evidence that regularly drinking green tea may even help prevent or slow the growth of certain cancers. For maximum health benefits, choose loose-leaf green tea.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Hot peppers | Chinese researchers studied nearly 500,000 people. Those who ate fiery foods at least one day a week over four years cut their risk of dying by 10 percent; and those who ate it three to seven days a week saw a 15 percent drop. The researchers credit capsaicin, the compound that makes spicy foods hot. It has anti-obesity, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant and anticancer properties.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Nuts | They’re rich in heart-protective unsaturated fat and provide an excellent source of (non-meat) protein.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Oats | They’re are one of the best sources of soluble fiber, which helps reduce LDL (“bad”) cholesterol and control blood sugar, which cuts your risk of developing heart disease and diabetes.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Salmon | It’s one the best sources of omega-3 fatty acids, a noted “brain food” that may reduce the risk of dementia and cognitive decline. Omega-3 also decreases the risk of abnormal heartbeats, lowers triglyceride levels, slows the growth of artery-clogging fat deposits and reduces blood pressure.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Soy | It’s rich in flavonoids, compounds that protect the heart and guard against breast cancer. Fermented soy foods contribute to a healthy intestinal ecology.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Spinach | One cup of spinach contains as much bone-building calcium as one cup of milk, and it’s also a good source of magnesium, a mineral that helps your body’s muscular and cardiovascular systems function. Plus, spinach is loaded with vitamins A and E, antioxidants that support the health of your cells.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Sweet potatoes | They’re a good source of potassium, which can help lower your blood pressure. They’re also packed with vitamin A, important for vision, bone health, reproduction and cell growth and maintenance.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Yogurt | It’s loaded with probiotics, “friendly bacteria” similar to the bacteria naturally found in the gut. There is emerging evidence that regularly consuming yogurt and other sources of probiotics can help bolster general wellness, prevent certain cancers, boost the immune system, improve digestion, protect against disease and treat some health conditions including diarrhea, urinary tract infections and irritable bowel syndrome.  Getty Images/iStockphoto Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay 1 of 13 2 of 13 3 of 13 4 of 13 5 of 13 6 of 13 7 of 13 8 of 13 9 of 13 10 of 13 11 of 13 12 of 13 13 of 13 Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide Estrella Lakeside Market Local farmers sell fresh-picked vegetables. Dine on Mexican food or hot dogs while shopping for kettle corn, fresh apple juice, tamales, fresh-baked bread, apple butter, baked goods and tapenade. Bouncy house and other activities at this kid-friendly market.
Details: 10 a.m.-1 p.m. third Saturday of the month. 10336 S. Estrella Parkway, Goodyear. azfarmersmarkets.us .
